bibl.title: Despatch from Thomas Brown to Hamilton Fish, November 25, 1870
Despatches from United States Consuls in Boma, 1888-1895
bibl.publisher: National Archives and Records Service General Services Administration

div1.p: United States Consulate Bathurst River, Gambia 25th November 1870

Sir, I crave leave to bring under your notice the fact, that American Commerce has been very much depressed on the West Coast of Africa by the contenance of New tax of one coast sold new found weight on groundnuts or ground peas.

Nuts tax was imposed during the Rebellion on the Southern States- the high prices threw current in the United States for this article enables Importer to pay it easily, but now prices nuts very low and duty.
accounts
div1.ab: To the Honorable Hamilton Fish Secretary of State Washington
div1.p:
amounts virtually to a prohibition American goods can be imported via France abd England and bartered for Ground Nuts to better advantage than, name article can be imported direct from via United States and barter for Groundnuts to be imported here in return.
I am Sir Your the obident Servant Thomas Brown Consul pro: term
